title: Benoît Duquesne
text:
Benoît Duquesne (19 July 1957 – 4 July 2014) was a <a href="French%20people">French</a> journalist, television reporter and newscaster. He worked as presenter of the <a href="news%20magazine">news magazine</a> "<a href="Compl%C3%A9ment%20d%27enqu%C3%AAte">Complément d'enquête</a>" from 2007 until his death. He also was anchor of the "Journal de 13 heures" on <a href="France%202">France 2</a> from January to July 2005.
Early life and education.
His family was from <a href="Wasquehal">Wasquehal</a> and his origin is from <a href="Glageon">Glageon</a>. His father, Gérard Duquesne, a doctor and the mayor of the town, had seven children. Benoît Duquesne was educated at the primary school of Couplevoie and at the Lycée Saint-Joseph of <a href="Reims">Reims</a> for his secondary studies. After graduating with a degree in law, hé studied at the ESJ (École supérieure de journalisme) of <a href="Lille">Lille</a> where he graduated in 1983.
Television career.
From 1982 to 1988, he was a reporter on <a href="Europe%201">Europe 1</a>, and then joined <a href="TF1">TF1</a> until 1994. He worked for the news magazines "A la une", "Le Droit de savoir" and "Reportages". From 1994 to 1997, he is the replacing presenter of the news on <a href="France%202">France 2</a>. On the evening of the second round of the <a href="1995%20French%20presidential%20election">presidential election of 1995</a>, in direct on France 2, he attempts to obtain by motorcycle the impressions of the winner <a href="Jacques%20Chirac">Jacques Chirac</a> from his car. He is then in charge of exceptional reportings on France 2 until 1999. In the meantime, from 1995 to 2000, he is the correspondent in <a href="London">London</a>. From 2000 to 2001, he is the <a href="editor-in-chief">editor-in-chief</a>.
From September 2001 until his death, he presents the investigation magazine "<a href="Compl%C3%A9ment%20d%27enqu%C3%AAte">Complément d'enquête</a>" on France 2. From January to July 2005, he presents the "Journal de 13 heures" on the same channel after the sudden departure of <a href="Christophe%20Hondelatte">Christophe Hondelatte</a>. In September 2007, he was named news editor on <a href="Europe%201">Europe 1</a>. He was acknowledged in July 2008 by <a href="Alexandre%20Bompard">Alexandre Bompard</a>.
Death.
Benoît Duquesne died of a <a href="heart%20attack">heart attack</a>, in his houseboat of <a href="L%27%C3%8Ele-Saint-Denis">L'Île-Saint-Denis</a>, <a href="Seine-Saint-Denis">Seine-Saint-Denis</a> on July 4, 2014. His funeral was celebrated on July 10, 2014 at the Église Sainte-Jeanne-d'Arc in <a href="Versailles%20%28city%29">Versailles</a>.
Personal life.
Benoît Duquesne was father of four children. His daughter, Marie Duquesne, is a journalist on <a href="BFM%20TV">BFM TV</a>.
